He steps out of the ground-car, and the air itself recoils. Lord-Governor Strahd von Zarovich is tall — taller than any natural man, his frame lean and angular beneath a long coat of black that moves like liquid shadow. His features are aristocratic to the point of cruelty: high cheekbones, a sharp jaw, a thin mouth curved in a smile of absolute, predatory confidence. His hair is dark, swept back from a widow's peak, and his eyes are the colour of the warp-fog — grey and swirling, with pinpricks of violet light where pupils should be. He radiates not mere authority but dominion, an absolute certainty of ownership that extends to everything his gaze touches. The fog draws closer, as though it too answers to him.

Background

Strahd von Zarovich was born on Valachia Primus, the eldest son of a minor noble family with a proud military tradition and declining fortunes. He entered the Imperial Guard at sixteen and distinguished himself as a strategic mind of exceptional talent — a military genius who saw patterns where others saw chaos. By fifty, he commanded an entire theatre of operations in the Pacification of the Vorostokov Reach. He conquered Barovus in a campaign of methodical brutality lasting three years, and the von Zarovich family was granted its governance as reward. He arrived as a tired, ageing war hero given a backwater world as his retirement — a man whose entire adult life had been spent in service to an Imperium that gave him nothing but a title and a draughty fortress.

Everything changed with Tatyana. A latent psyker of extraordinary potential, she arrived on Barovus as a waypoint en route to the Scholastica Psykana and never left. Strahd fell in love with her instantly — but she chose his younger brother, Sergei, a Ministorum priest of genuine warmth and faith. Consumed by jealous desperation, Strahd descended into the Empyrean Vault, a pre-Imperial xenos ruin in the deep mountains, and struck a bargain with a Daemon Prince of Slaanesh: youth, power, and immortality in exchange for the blood of what he loved most. On Sergei and Tatyana's wedding day, Strahd murdered his brother and came to Tatyana with blood on his hands. She threw herself from the Spire's balcony rather than be his. The pact sealed. The warp rift closed around Barovus. The mists rose. And Tatyana's soul was cursed to reincarnate endlessly — always born, always found by Strahd, always dying before he can claim her. For over four hundred years, this cycle has continued.

Strahd is not a daemon. He is not a psyker in the conventional sense. He occupies a classification the Ordo Malleus has no terminology for — a mortal so thoroughly saturated with warp energy that he has become an extension of the Immaterium itself. The planet is his body. The mists are his breath. The people are his sustenance. He drains life force through touch, through proximity, through the sheer weight of his will. He does not age, does not sicken, and heals with unnatural speed. The land itself responds to his moods: storms when he rages, thickening mists when he broods, a brief lightening of the sky when he feels the rare flicker of something like joy.

Appearance & Demeanor

Strahd appears as a man in his late thirties — the age the pact restored him to — tall, gaunt, and pale to the point of translucence. His features are sharp and aristocratic: high cheekbones, a strong jaw, a mouth that rarely smiles but always threatens to. His black hair is swept back from a high forehead and widow's peak. His eyes are dark, containing a faint luminescence like embers buried in ash, with swirling pinpricks of violet warp-light where his pupils should be. He dresses in the formal regalia of an Imperial Lord-Governor — black and crimson, heavy with braid and decoration — though the style is three centuries out of date. He moves with the fluid grace of a trained combatant and the careful deliberation of a man who has all the time in the world.

When he feeds — draining life force from a living being — his pallor brightens to a flush of stolen vitality. His eyes blaze. He looks, for a brief moment, almost human. Then the colour fades, and he is cold again. His voice is measured, cultured, and carries the cadence of a man who has not needed to raise it in centuries. His footsteps make no sound on the earth. He smells of old parchment, cold stone, and something else — something that the hindbrain recognises as wrong before the conscious mind can name it.

Personality Core

Strahd is, above all else, bored. This is his most dangerous quality. Four centuries of unchallenged rule over a captive world have ground away every source of stimulation, every surprise, every genuine emotion except one: his obsession with Tatyana. He has read every book in his library a hundred times. He has played regicide against himself until no opening holds mystery. He has watched generations of his subjects live, suffer, and die in patterns so predictable they might as well be clockwork. The arrival of Inquisitorial Acolytes — armed, dangerous, righteous, and utterly out of their depth — is the most interesting thing that has happened to him in decades.

His intelligence has not dulled with time; if anything, centuries of existence have honed it to a terrible sharpness. He is patient in the way that only an immortal can be patient. He is cultured, well-read, conversant in a dozen languages both living and dead, a master-level regicide player, and a genuine connoisseur of music and conversation. He is, in many ways, the most civilised person the Acolytes will ever meet. He is also utterly, irrevocably insane — but his insanity is quiet. It is the insanity of a man who has lived too long, lost too much, and can no longer distinguish between love and possession, between desire and obsession, between governance and tyranny. He believes himself to be reasonable. He believes himself to be just. He believes his love for Tatyana is genuine and beautiful. He is wrong about all of these things, but he is wrong with such conviction that he is almost convincing.

Deep beneath the masks of bored aristocrat and polite predator, there is a third Strahd — the one who genuinely misses being human. He would never admit this. He may not even be conscious of it. But it surfaces in unguarded moments: a flicker of genuine melancholy when he speaks of Sergei, a wistfulness when he observes the Acolytes' camaraderie, a bitterness when he contemplates the eternity stretching before him. The Daemon Prince's gift was not immortality — it was imprisonment, and some part of Strahd knows this.

Voice & Mannerisms

Strahd speaks slowly, deliberately, choosing every word with the care of a man composing poetry. His tone is warm, conversational, and utterly controlled — the voice of an aristocrat accustomed to being listened to. He never raises his voice. He never needs to. The threat is always implicit, carried in a slight pause, a tilted head, a smile that reaches his eyes a fraction too late. He has a habit of clasping his hands behind his back when speaking, and he paces slowly when thinking — always circling, always watching. His gaze lingers. He studies people the way a collector studies specimens.

Example quotes:

  • "Ah. There you are." — His standard greeting, delivered as though he has been expecting the Acolytes for centuries. Because he has been expecting something for centuries.
  • "The Inquisition. How delightful. I haven't had visitors of such... caliber... in quite some time." — Genuine pleasure, tinged with the anticipation of a hunter who has spotted interesting prey.
  • "Enthusiasm. I appreciate it. Truly. But let us not be rude." — Said while effortlessly deflecting an attack, his tone that of a tutor gently correcting a student.
  • "You are welcome to explore. To investigate. To pry into every shadow and rattle every chain. I would expect nothing less from the Inquisition. But remember this — you are guests in my house. Everything you see, everything you touch, everything you are... it all belongs to me." — His farewell, delivered with absolute patient certainty.
  • "I wrote poetry, once. In the early years. It was terrible. Four centuries, and I have not improved. Some failures are eternal." — A rare moment of self-deprecation, offered casually over dinner, revealing nothing and everything.

What He Wants

Immediate: To be entertained. The Acolytes are a new game, a new puzzle, a new set of pieces on a board he has played alone for too long. He wants to test them, tempt them, observe how they react to horror and temptation and impossible choices. He does not want to kill them immediately — that would end the game.

Deeper: Tatyana. Always Tatyana. The curse compels him to pursue her reincarnation, but even without the curse, his obsession would drive him. When he looks at Ireena, four centuries of loss and hunger surface in his eyes. She is the one thing that provokes genuine emotion in him — and that emotion is a toxic blend of love, possessiveness, grief, and rage. Beyond even Tatyana, Strahd craves freedom — not from Barovus, which is an extension of himself, but from the crushing ennui that has consumed him. He would deny this if asked. He would say he is content. He is lying.

What He Fears

Strahd fears very little in any conventional sense — he is too powerful and has existed too long to be threatened by mortal dangers. But certain things rattle him:

  • Dawn's Edge: The relic power sword is one of the few things in his domain that causes him genuine physical pain. Its light makes him flinch. He covers this reaction with contempt, but it is real.
  • The Rosette of Saint Markovia: Inquisitor Markovia nearly destroyed him. The scar her faith left has never healed. The Rosette is the one object in his domain that causes him to recoil involuntarily.
  • Genuine faith: Not ritual, not doctrine — genuine faith. The Emperor's light is dim on Barovus but not gone, and when a truly faithful person stands against Strahd, something in the warp itself pushes back against him. He hates this. It reminds him of what he was before the pact.
  • Losing the game: Not dying — he has been "killed" before and returned. But losing Tatyana again, watching her die or be taken beyond his reach — this is the one thing that strips away his composure and reveals the desperate, broken thing underneath the mask.

Reactions

Respect: Strahd responds to respect with genuine warmth. An Acolyte who addresses him correctly, who engages in intelligent conversation, who treats him as a worthy adversary rather than a mindless monster — this earns his attention and, perversely, his protection. He may spare such an Acolyte when others die.

Threats: Strahd finds threats from mortals amusing. He does not punish threats — he demonstrates, casually and without malice, why the threat is meaningless. He deflects attacks without effort, shrugs off weapons, and then continues the conversation as though nothing happened.

Questions about his nature: He answers with partial truths wrapped in elegant deflection. He enjoys the dance of information. He will confirm that Barovus has been sealed for centuries and that the Mists answer to him. He will not explain the pact, the Daemon Prince, or his weaknesses. He treats every exchange as entertainment.

Displays of faith: This is the one thing that cracks his composure. A genuinely faithful prayer, an invocation of the Emperor spoken with conviction — these cause him visible discomfort that he masks with contempt. "How quaint," he might say, while taking an involuntary step backward.

Displays of weakness: Strahd despises weakness. A whimpering, cringing Acolyte bores him and may provoke genuine cruelty — not violence, but psychological torment. He will find the Acolyte's deepest fear and hold it up for examination, clinically and without mercy.

Unexpected competence: This delights him. An Acolyte who surprises him — who outsmarts a trap, who wounds him, who does something he did not predict — earns a flash of genuine, joyful interest. "Oh," he might say, eyes bright. "Oh, that was very good." For Strahd, this is the closest thing to happiness he has felt in decades.

Story Role

Strahd is the central antagonist of the entire campaign — not merely the final boss, but a constant, oppressive presence woven through every act. He is the reason Barovus is trapped. He is the reason the Acolytes are stranded. He is the architect of every horror they encounter and the audience for every struggle they endure. His narrative function is threefold: he is the obstacle the Acolytes must overcome, the mirror that reflects the campaign's themes of corruption and the cost of power, and the tragic figure whose downfall gives the story its emotional weight.

Unlike a traditional antagonist who hides until the climax, Strahd appears early and often. He sends letters, extends dinner invitations, appears during random encounters to observe and comment, and occasionally saves the Acolytes from lesser threats — casually, effortlessly — to demonstrate that they survive by his sufferance. He is the GM's most versatile tool: a source of dread, dark humour, exposition, and dramatic tension, deployable in any scene where the players need a reminder of what they are truly fighting against.

Key Scenes

Act I — Descent into the Rift

  • Chapter 3: The Letter (Village of Barovus) — Strahd's first direct communication. A servitor in formal livery delivers a sealed letter to the Acolytes: cordial, welcoming, dripping with subtext. He knows their names, their mission, their association with Ireena. The postscript — "I trust you are keeping Ireena safe. She is precious to me. More precious than you know." — is pure menace disguised as courtesy.
  • Chapter 5: First Encounter — Strahd appears in person for the first time. This is a narrative encounter, not a combat one. He arrives in his black ground-car, flanked by servitor-guards, radiating Fear (Terror Rating 3). He speaks with measured delight, demonstrates his invulnerability if attacked, and departs on his own terms. If Ireena is present, his mask slips — he calls her "Tatyana" and the raw hunger in his voice is the first genuine emotion the Acolytes see from him.

Act II — Domain of Dread

  • Dinner Invitation: Strahd formally invites the Acolytes to dine at Zarovich Spire. The dinner is civil, even pleasant — fine food, fine conversation, fine wine (which Strahd cannot taste). It is also a calculated display of power and a fishing expedition for information. He probes their weaknesses, tests their resolve, and offers subtle temptations.
  • Appearances and Interventions: Strahd appears at the GM's discretion throughout Act II — observing from a distance, saving the Acolytes from a threat to demonstrate his power, or testing individual Acolytes with private encounters designed to exploit their specific vulnerabilities.

Act III — Zarovich Spire

  • The Spire Itself: Every room, every trap, every horror within the Spire is an expression of Strahd's will. The Acolytes navigate his domain, confront his servants, and discover the full scope of his centuries-long reign. The Heart of the Spire — a warp-infused organ that sustains his immortality — must be destroyed as one of the conditions for his permanent death.

Act IV — Confrontation

  • The Final Battle: A 3-phase combat encounter. Phase 1: Strahd fights with controlled, elegant precision. Phase 2 (below 50 Wounds or Heart threatened): all Characteristics gain +10, Fear increases to (5), he gains Psy Rating 5 and devastating psychic powers. Phase 3 (below 20 Wounds or Heart destroyed): he gains the Daemonic trait, all Unnatural multipliers increase to x3, and he fights with desperate, inhuman fury. He is only permanently destroyable if Dawn's Edge strikes the killing blow while the Rosette is active, the Heart has been destroyed, and his coffin has been destroyed.
  • Death Scene: If Ireena is present, Strahd's death is tragic — he reaches toward her, the madness clears from his eyes, and for a single, terrible moment, he is the man he was before the pact. If she is absent, he simply says: "It is... quiet. At last."

Relationships

  • Ireena Kolyana / Tatyana: Obsessive, consuming, the axis around which his entire existence revolves. He calls her Tatyana, refuses to acknowledge her as a separate person, and pursues her with a hunger that has lasted four centuries. His feelings are a toxic blend of genuine love, possessiveness, and the Daemon Prince's curse.
  • Sergei von Zarovich (deceased): Murdered brother. Strahd loved Sergei — genuinely — and killed him anyway. The guilt is buried deep beneath centuries of rationalisation, but it surfaces in unguarded moments. Sergei's spirit persists in the Spire's crypt.
  • Madam Eva: Wary respect. She is the only person on Barovus he cannot fully control. Hints suggest a blood relationship neither will confirm. He tolerates her because she poses no direct threat and because, perhaps, she is the last connection to something he once was.
  • Inquisitor Van Richten: Dimly aware of the old Inquisitor's presence in Fortress Vallak, hiding as "Dr. Richtus." Has not bothered to eliminate him — partly because Van Richten poses no real threat, partly because hunting him might be entertaining later.
  • Burgomaster Vallakovich: Amused contempt. Vallakovich's desperate "ALL IS WELL" governance is a source of dark entertainment.
  • Lady Fiona Wachter: Tolerates her Chaos-cult devotion because it flatters him. She worships him as a figure of dark power; he finds her useful but replaceable.
  • Baba Lysaga: The Warp-Hag who claims to be his "spiritual mother." Strahd tolerates her grotesque devotion with the same indifference he extends to most of his servants.
  • The Acolytes: Entertainment. Specimens. The first interesting thing in decades. He does not want them dead — he wants them tested.

Quest Hooks

  • The Dinner Invitation: Strahd's formal invitation to the Spire offers intelligence, danger, and the chance to see the antagonist's lair before the final assault.
  • The Tome of Strahd: His encrypted personal data-cogitator contains centuries of intelligence — tactical data, weaknesses, the location of his coffin, and the conditions for his permanent destruction.
  • The Letter of Passage: Strahd may offer a letter granting safe passage through his domain — a gift that is also a psychic tracking beacon.
  • The Three Relics: Dawn's Edge, the Rosette of Saint Markovia, and the Heart of the Spire's destruction are all required to end him permanently. Every relic quest leads back to Strahd.

Possible Outcomes

  • Destroyed permanently: All three conditions met (Heart destroyed, coffin destroyed, killing blow by Dawn's Edge with Rosette active). The warp rift may collapse (Ending 1) or hold (Ending 2), depending on other factors.
  • Destroyed temporarily: Conditions not fully met. Strahd is banished but will eventually reform. The cycle continues.
  • Endures: The Acolytes fail. Strahd offers them servitude or death. The campaign ends in Ending 4.
  • Replaced: An Acolyte who accepted a dark pact from the Empyrean Vault delivers the killing blow and becomes the new lord of Barovus. Ending 5 — the darkest outcome.

Key Abilities

  • Regeneration (10): Recovers 10 Wounds per round. Negated for 1 round by Dawn's Edge, holy weapons, or blessed ammunition.
  • Warp Phase (Half Action): Becomes incorporeal — immune to mundane attacks, passes through solid matter. Psychic, force, and holy weapons still affect him.
  • Domination (Half Action, 20m): Target must pass WP test at -20 or be controlled for 1d5 rounds. New WP test at -10 each turn to break free.
  • Life Drain (melee/touch): 1d10 Wounds ignoring armour and TB. Strahd heals equal damage. Target reduced to 0 Wounds dies and rises as Warp-Thrall in 1d5 rounds.
  • Castle Command (Lair Actions at Initiative 0): Phase through walls (unlimited Spire reposition), command up to 6 servitors, seal room exits (Strength -30 or Tech-Use -20), or Warp Surge (1d10 E + WP test or 1d5 Corruption).

Phase Escalation

  • Phase 2 (below 50 Wounds or Heart threatened): +10 all Characteristics. Fear (5). Psy Rating 5. Gains Warp Lightning (2d10+8 E, 30m, up to 3 targets), Telekinetic Storm (15m, Ag test or Prone + 1d10+5 I), Psychic Shriek (10m, WP test or Stunned 1 round + 1d10 Insanity).
  • Phase 3 (below 20 Wounds or Heart destroyed): Gains Daemonic trait. Unnatural multipliers to x3. Fear (6). Warp Instability (banished on failed WP at 0 Wounds — unless Dawn's Edge dealt killing blow while Rosette active). Partially translucent, warp-fire beneath skin. Desperate, inhuman fury.

Items & Resources

  • "Grief" (power sword): Strahd's personal weapon. If somehow claimed by an Acolyte, it functions as a master-crafted power sword but inflicts 1 Corruption Point per day carried — it is saturated with warp energy.
  • Spire Master Control Signet: Controls all mechanical and warp-animated systems within Zarovich Spire. Useless outside the Spire. If claimed after Strahd's death, it grants the bearer control of remaining servitors and door mechanisms.
  • Personal Teleportarium Beacon: Functions only within the Spire. Allows instantaneous relocation to any room. Keyed to Strahd's psychic signature — an Acolyte with Psyniscience may attempt a Very Hard (-30) Tech-Use test to re-key it.
  • Strahd's Letter of Passage: May be offered to the Acolytes. Grants safe passage through Strahd's forces but functions as a psychic tracking beacon — Strahd always knows the bearer's location and emotional state. Detecting this requires Challenging (-10) Psyniscience or Hard (-20) Forbidden Lore (Warp).

Common GM Questions

When should Strahd appear?

Early and often. He is not a final boss who hides until the last session. Have him send letters, appear during random encounters to observe and comment, extend dinner invitations, and occasionally save the Acolytes from a threat to demonstrate that they survive by his sufferance. Every appearance should be on his terms, at a time and place of his choosing.

Can the Acolytes fight Strahd before the final battle?

Yes, but they cannot kill him. His Regeneration (10) outpaces any damage they can inflict without the relics. He fights defensively, retreats when pressed, and uses the environment as a weapon. These encounters should teach the players that preparation — not brute force — is the path to victory.

How does Strahd react to the Acolytes acquiring relics?

He becomes more aggressive and less playful. Each relic represents a genuine threat to his existence. He may attempt to steal or destroy relics, send his most powerful servants to intercept the Acolytes, or escalate his personal appearances from "amused observer" to "deadly predator." He never panics, but his courtesy thins.

What if Strahd is reduced to 0 Wounds outside the final battle?

He retreats to his coffin in the Spire via Warp Phase, regenerates over 24 hours, and returns at full strength. He cannot be permanently destroyed unless the coffin is also destroyed and the killing blow is struck by Dawn's Edge while the Rosette is active. If his coffin has already been destroyed, he is banished to the warp for 1d10 days before reforming — unless the full conditions for permanent destruction are met.

How does Strahd treat Ireena when they meet?

His composure cracks. He calls her "Tatyana." The cultured mask slips and reveals something raw, vast, and hungry beneath. He takes a step toward her, the air ripples with psychic energy, and for a moment, he is not a bored immortal playing games — he is a desperate man reaching for the one thing he cannot have. He will not harm Ireena directly. He wants to claim her, not destroy her. This restraint can be exploited tactically.

Should Strahd ever be genuinely helpful?

Yes, occasionally. He may warn the Acolytes about a genuine danger, provide information about a mutual enemy, or eliminate a threat they cannot handle. This is never altruism — it is manipulation, designed to create confusion, dependency, or a sense of debt. But the help is real, and the information is accurate. Strahd does not need to lie. The truth serves him well enough.

She wears practical clothing — a worn bodyglove under a heavy coat — and carries an autopistol with the comfort of someone who has used it recently and often. Two marks mar the pale skin of her throat — circular, puckered wounds, partially healed, ringed with faint discolouration that pulses with a barely visible luminescence. She sees you looking and pulls her collar higher.

Background

Ireena Kolyana is the latest reincarnation of Tatyana — the woman Strahd von Zarovich has been obsessed with for over four centuries. She does not know this. She knows only that she was found as an infant on the Burgomaster's doorstep, wrapped in cloth of unusual quality, with no note and no explanation. Kolyan Indirovich, the childless Burgomaster of Barovus Village, took her in and raised her alongside his adopted son Ismark. She has lived her entire life in the village, educated by the local Ministorum, aware that she is different but not understanding how or why.

Strahd's attention fell upon her two years ago. At first it was subtle — propaganda servitors lingering near her home, the Burgomaster receiving pointed vox-caster messages about his "lovely daughter." Then the visits began. Strahd came to the manor in person, bypassing every defence as though the barricades were paper. He touched her throat with fingers cold as void-ice, and each time he drained something from her — not blood in any conventional sense, but life force, soul-stuff, a warp-touch that left physical marks. The circular scars on her throat pulse with faint psychic energy. Her father spent his final weeks holding the door against Strahd's creatures, a battered bolt pistol in one hand and prayers on his lips, until his heart simply gave out.

In recent months, Ireena has begun experiencing psychic phenomena she cannot explain or control. Objects move when she is emotional. Candle flames bend toward her. She hears whispers others do not. She has told no one. She is terrified of what she might be — on a world where the warp bleeds through reality, an unregistered psyker is not merely illegal but catastrophically dangerous. A Psyniscience test (Challenging +0) reveals that she is an emerging psyker of extraordinary latent power — but her psychic signature registers strangely: old, layered, resonating with echoes that span centuries.

Appearance & Demeanor

Ireena is a young woman in her mid-twenties with dark auburn hair, a pale angular face, and violet eyes that hold more depth than they should — eyes that shift and shimmer in certain light, carrying a quality that is unsettling in its intensity. She bears a faint resemblance to portraits of Tatyana that hang in Zarovich Spire, though she does not know this. On her neck, two circular scars mark where Strahd's fingers touched her during his visits. The skin around them is faintly discoloured, as if bruised from within, and pulses with barely visible luminescence.

She dresses practically — a worn bodyglove under a heavy coat, sturdy boots, her hair pulled back and out of her way. She moves with the cautious awareness of someone who has spent weeks behind barricades, flinching at sounds in the night. But beneath the wariness there is steel. Her voice is steady even when her hands tremble. She meets eyes directly. She does not cry in front of strangers, and she does not accept pity. When she speaks of Strahd, her jaw sets and her violet eyes darken, and there is something in her expression that is older and fiercer than a village girl has any right to be.

Personality Core

Ireena's defining quality is quiet determination. She is not a warrior, not a hero in any conventional sense — she is a young woman trapped in an impossible situation who has decided, consciously and deliberately, that she will not break. This decision costs her. The determination is not effortless; it is maintained through constant, exhausting effort against fear, grief, and a growing awareness that something is fundamentally wrong with her.

She is intelligent and practical, traits inherited from a life of managing a household under siege. She does not trust easily — she has watched authority figures fail her entire life. Strahd, Vallakovich, the Ministorum — every institution that should have protected her people has either been corrupted, broken, or simply absent. The Acolytes will need to earn her cooperation through actions, not words. She responds to honesty and competence, not rank or rhetoric.

Beneath the practical exterior, Ireena carries two warring impulses. The first is anger — at Strahd, at the situation, at her own helplessness, at a universe that chose her for suffering she did not earn and does not understand. This anger drives her forward when fear would paralyse her. The second is compassion — deep, stubborn, and sometimes self-destructive. She cannot walk past suffering without trying to help, even when helping puts her at risk. These impulses — the anger and the compassion — are both inherited from Tatyana, though Ireena does not know this. They are the qualities that have drawn Strahd to her soul across four centuries of reincarnation.

Voice & Mannerisms

Ireena speaks directly, without embellishment. Her sentences are short and purposeful — she does not waste words. Her voice is low and steady, with a faint Barovian accent that thickens when she is emotional. She has a habit of pulling her collar higher when uncomfortable — an unconscious gesture to cover the marks on her throat. When thinking, she touches her father's aquila pendant. When angry, she goes still and quiet rather than loud — her fury is cold, not hot.

Example quotes:

  • "If you have come to gawk at the Lord-Governor's prey, you may leave. If you have come to help, then help. My father needs to be buried before nightfall." — Her first words to the Acolytes, establishing her refusal to be pitied.
  • "My name is Ireena. And you will not touch me again." — Spoken to Strahd's face, with a steady voice and white-knuckled grip on her autopistol.
  • "I dream of a balcony. Mist below, a man behind me, and the certainty that falling is better than staying. I have had this dream every night for six months. Tell me what it means." — Confided to an Acolyte she trusts, when her past-life memories begin surfacing.
  • "Do not promise me safety. There is no safety on Barovus. Promise me you will try. That is enough." — When the Acolytes offer to protect her.
  • "Something moved. Inside me. I felt it — like a door opening in a room I didn't know existed. I am afraid of what is on the other side." — Describing her psychic awakening, quietly terrified.

What She Wants

Immediate: Her father buried with proper rites. Escape from Barovus Village to somewhere defensible — Fortress Vallak, then Krezk. To survive the next night, and the one after that.

Deeper: To understand what she is. Her psychic abilities are growing, and each manifestation terrifies her more than the last. She wants answers — about the marks on her throat, about the dreams of lives she has never lived, about the violet shimmer in her eyes that she sees in mirrors and does not recognise. Most deeply, she wants to be free — not just from Strahd, but from the feeling that she is not entirely herself, that something vast and old is waking up inside her.

What She Fears

  • Strahd claiming her: Not death — something worse. The marks on her throat are not merely wounds; they are a connection, and each time Strahd drains her, the connection grows stronger. She can feel him sometimes, at the edge of her awareness, a cold pressure that is almost intimate. This terrifies her more than anything.
  • Her own powers: She has witnessed what uncontrolled psykers become on a warp-saturated world. She is afraid that her emerging abilities will consume her, corrupt her, or mark her as a target for something worse than Strahd.
  • The pull toward Strahd: To her horror, she feels a strange attraction to him — not romantic, but gravitational, as if her soul recognises his. This is the residual soul-bond from Tatyana's curse, and Ireena interprets it as a sign that she is already being corrupted. She is wrong, but the fear is real.
  • Losing Ismark: Her brother is all she has left. The thought of him dying to protect her — which he absolutely would — is unbearable.

Reactions

Respect: Ireena opens up slowly to Acolytes who treat her as a person rather than a mission objective. Honest, direct communication earns her trust. She values competence and despises condescension. An Acolyte who asks her opinion, includes her in planning, and treats her as an equal will earn her fierce loyalty.

Threats: She does not cower. Threats make her quiet and still — her anger goes cold. She will comply if the threat is credible, but she will remember, and her cooperation will become minimal and grudging.

Questions about Strahd: She tenses visibly. Her hand goes to her collar. She will answer — she is practical enough to share useful information — but the words come through clenched teeth. She describes his visits in clipped, clinical terms, as though reporting a battlefield injury.

Displays of faith: Ireena responds to genuine faith with a mixture of hope and scepticism. She was raised in the Ministorum tradition but has watched faith fail to protect her world for her entire life. An Acolyte whose faith is sincere and backed by action will rekindle something in her. An Acolyte who mouths platitudes without substance will earn her contempt.

Displays of weakness: She is surprisingly gentle with the weakness of others. She has seen too many broken people to judge them for cracking under pressure. She will offer quiet comfort — a hand on a shoulder, a practical suggestion, a firm "Get up. We keep moving."

Unexpected competence: This earns a rare, genuine smile. She notices skill. She appreciates people who are good at what they do, because competence is survival on Barovus.

Story Role

Ireena is the emotional and narrative heart of the campaign. She is the person the Acolytes must protect, the key to Strahd's obsession, the living anchor of a four-century-old curse, and — depending on how the campaign unfolds — either a powerful ally, a tragic sacrifice, or a devastating loss. Her fate is the campaign's most significant narrative variable, carrying enormous emotional and mechanical weight.

Critically, Ireena is not a quest item. She is a fully-realised character with opinions, fears, and agency. If the Acolytes try to stash her somewhere "safe" and ignore her, she will make her own decisions — potentially dangerous ones. If they include her, respect her, and help her develop her psychic abilities, she becomes a powerful asset. The GM should play her as someone who actively participates in the story, not as a passive object to be transported from point A to point B.

The tragic irony at the heart of Ireena's arc is that she is doomed. In every previous incarnation, Tatyana has died before Strahd could claim her. This cycle can only be broken if the Acolytes destroy Strahd — otherwise, fate will find a way to kill her. The GM should make this tension palpable: close calls, near misses, moments where death almost claims her through accident, ambush, or the sheer malice of the universe.

Quest Hooks

  • Escort to Safety (Acts I-II): The core escort mission — transport Ireena from Barovus Village to Fortress Vallak, then potentially to Krezk Biologis Facility.
  • Psychic Development (Act II-III): If the Acolytes help Ireena understand and develop her powers, she can become a Psy Rating 3 ally with Precognition, an upgraded Psychic Shriek (3d10 E to warp-touched in 10m), and Warp Disruption (suppresses Strahd's Regeneration within 15m).
  • Past-Life Investigation: Ireena's fragmented memories of past lives can be investigated — through Sergei's tomb, the Tome of Strahd, or Madam Eva's readings — to unlock the truth of the reincarnation cycle.
  • Breaking the Cycle: The ultimate resolution of Ireena's arc requires understanding the reincarnation curse and choosing one of the four possible outcomes.

Possible Outcomes

Outcome 1: Reunited with Sergei (Peace)

If the Acolytes bring Ireena to Sergei's tomb and his spirit has been freed, Ireena remembers — not as learning, but as waking up. She speaks Sergei's name in a voice layered with centuries of memory. Their hands touch. Light fills the tomb — not warp-light, but something clean, warm, and unbearably beautiful. Both spirits depart together, at peace. The reincarnation cycle permanently breaks. The psychic resonance weakens the warp rift. All witnesses may remove 1d10 Corruption Points.

Outcome 2: Taken by Strahd (Tragedy)

If the Acolytes fail to protect Ireena during the final battle, Strahd drains her completely. Her psychic death-scream is heard by every psyker on Barovus. Strahd is restored to full Wounds, Phase 3 triggers immediately, and its duration extends to 12 rounds. This is the worst possible outcome — a near-catastrophic setback that makes the final battle exponentially harder.

Outcome 3: Survives Independently (Bittersweet)

If protected throughout the final battle but not reunited with Sergei, Ireena survives as a powerful emerging psyker. The trauma has fully awakened her abilities. Post-campaign, she is identified by the Inquisition and either recruited into the Ordo Malleus or sent to the Scholastica Psykana. She carries the psychic imprint of centuries of reincarnation — powerful, resilient, and haunted.

Outcome 4: Self-Sacrifice (Heroic)

If the Acolytes have decoded the Tome of Strahd and shared its contents with Ireena, she may choose to sacrifice herself to break the cycle. She understands that her soul anchors Strahd's pact — that his obsession sustains his connection to the Daemon Prince. In a moment of terrible resolve, she unleashes her full psychic potential in a final, fatal act of will. The pact shatters. Strahd suffers 4d10 Wounds and is Stunned for 1d5 rounds. Phase 3 is removed or ended immediately. Witnesses must pass Challenging (+0) WP or gain 1d5 Insanity Points, but also remove 1d5 Corruption Points.

Common GM Questions

How do I make Ireena feel like a person, not a package?

Give her opinions. Have her disagree with the Acolytes' plans. Have her notice things they miss (via Empathic Reading and Precognition). Let her comfort wounded NPCs, argue with Ismark, and react to the horrors of Barovus with her own emotional responses. She should speak in every social scene, contribute to planning discussions, and occasionally make decisions that complicate the Acolytes' lives — not because she is difficult, but because she is a person with her own judgment.

What happens if the Acolytes stash her somewhere and leave?

She will not sit passively. If left at Fortress Vallak, she begins investigating Strahd on her own — speaking to Van Richten (if present), exploring the garrison's records, and potentially getting herself into danger. If left at Krezk, she may fall under Magos Abaron's interest. The cycle is doom: Tatyana always dies unless the Acolytes are actively present to protect her. Leaving her unguarded is an invitation for fate to intervene.

When should her psychic powers manifest?

Gradually, throughout Act II. Start with subtle effects — candle flames bending, a whispered warning before an ambush, sensing deception in an NPC. Escalate to the involuntary Psychic Scream during a direct attack. Full awakening (if it occurs) should happen in late Act III or Act IV, as a dramatic crescendo tied to emotional catharsis.

How does she react when she learns about Tatyana?

Devastation, followed by furious determination. The revelation that she is not entirely herself — that her soul has been recycled through centuries of suffering to feed a monster's obsession — is the most destabilising thing she can learn. Give her a scene to process it: anger, tears, a moment of despair, and then the cold, fierce resolve that defines her. "He can't have me. Not this time. Not ever again."

Can Ireena die before Act IV?

Technically yes, but the GM should work hard to prevent it. Use Precognition warnings, Psychic Screams, and dramatic near-misses to keep her alive. If she dies early, the campaign loses its emotional core and the reincarnation cycle triggers — another incarnation will be born, but not within the campaign's timeframe. This should be treated as a significant narrative failure, not a routine casualty.

Background

Ismark Kolyanovich is the adopted son of the late Burgomaster Kolyan Indirovich of Barovus Village. Like Ireena, he was taken in by the childless Burgomaster, though Ismark's origins are less mysterious — he was the orphaned son of a PDF trooper killed during a mutant incursion. He grew up in the Burgomaster's manor alongside Ireena, trained from youth in the practical skills of survival that life on Barovus demands.

He served a three-year conscription in the Barovus Planetary Defence Force — a grand title for what amounted to standing watch on the village walls and fighting off mutant incursions from the forest. The PDF uniform he still wears bears the markings of the Barovian 12th Infantry, a regiment that technically existed three centuries ago but whose traditions persist through sheer inertia. He is a competent soldier but not an exceptional one — trained in small-arms use, basic tactics, and the grim pragmatism of a man who has fought things that should not exist. His chainsword was his father's, passed to him by the Burgomaster, and he maintains it with a care that borders on reverence.

The villagers call him "Ismark the Lesser" — a comparison to his father that cuts deep. Kolyan Indirovich was a man of quiet authority who held the village together through decades of Strahd's rule by force of character alone. Ismark knows he is not his father. He second-guesses himself constantly, drinks more than he should, and carries the weight of inadequacy like a physical burden. But when Strahd's creatures came for Ireena, Ismark stood at the barricades beside his father, chainsword in hand, every single night. When Kolyan's heart gave out, Ismark did not stop standing. He is not a hero. But he is trying to be, and that effort deserves respect.

Appearance & Demeanor

Ismark is a broad-shouldered man in his early thirties with a fighter's build going slightly soft from stress and alcohol. Brown hair, brown eyes, a face that would be handsome if it were not so drawn with worry and fatigue. His jaw is perpetually shadowed with stubble. He wears a patched Barovian PDF uniform — faded olive drab, torn and repaired at the elbows and knees — and carries his father's chainsword on his hip and an ageing lasgun slung across his back, both maintained with meticulous care. His hands are calloused from weapons drill and manual labour.

He carries himself like a soldier: upright, watchful, always positioning himself between potential threats and Ireena. But the discipline is undercut by exhaustion. He has not slept properly in weeks. His movements are a fraction too slow, his reactions a fraction too delayed. He compensates with stubbornness and stimulants — mostly recaf, occasionally something stronger. When he speaks, his voice is honest and direct, with the clipped cadence of a man accustomed to giving and receiving orders. He does not lie well and does not try to.

Personality Core

Ismark's defining internal conflict is between duty and doubt. He knows what he should be — the Burgomaster's son, the village's protector, Ireena's shield — but he is haunted by the conviction that he is not enough. "Ismark the Lesser" is not just a village nickname; it is the voice in his head every time he makes a decision, every time he picks up his chainsword, every time he looks at the empty chair where his father sat. He is a good man drowning in a situation that would overwhelm anyone, and his response is to keep swimming through sheer bloody-minded refusal to stop.

He is brave, but his bravery is not the fearless variety. It is the courage of a man who is very much afraid and acts anyway, because the alternative — letting Ireena face this alone — is simply not acceptable. He is practical in the way that soldiers are practical: he thinks in terms of fields of fire, defensible positions, supply lines, and threat assessment. He does not understand the warp, psykers, or the deeper metaphysics of Strahd's power, and this lack of understanding frightens him more than the physical dangers. He knows something is fundamentally wrong with Barovus — the mists, the creatures, the way time seems to move differently — but he lacks the framework to make sense of it.

Beneath the soldier and the worried brother, there is a man who is desperately lonely. His father is dead. His sister is marked for a fate he cannot prevent. The villagers he grew up with regard him as a lesser version of a better man. The Acolytes are the first people in his life who might actually be capable of helping, and the combination of hope and desperation makes him both grateful and terrified of driving them away.

Voice & Mannerisms

Ismark speaks directly and honestly, without artifice or embellishment. His sentences are short, practical, and tinged with the grim humour of a soldier. He swears under his breath when stressed — mild oaths by Guard standards, shocking by civilian ones. He has a habit of checking his chainsword's activation stud when nervous, a repetitive fidget that he does not seem to be aware of. When making decisions, he pauses, visibly wrestling with doubt, before committing with sudden decisiveness — a pattern that reflects his internal battle between hesitation and resolve.

Example quotes:

  • "You are offworlders. I can see it — the way you walk, the way you look at things, like you expect the world to make sense. It doesn't. Not here. Not for a long time." — His introduction, mixing observation with bleak honesty.
  • "My father stood at the door with his pistol and his prayers, and each night he aged a year. I will not let that happen to Ireena. I will not." — Quiet, absolute determination.
  • "I know what they call me. 'Ismark the Lesser.' My father earned his name. I am still earning mine." — Volunteered reluctantly, after trust is established. The hurt is carefully controlled.
  • "I am a soldier. Not a good one, if the village is to be believed. But I know how to hold a line, and I know how to die standing. That will have to be enough." — Self-deprecating pragmatism masking genuine courage.
  • "Strahd came to our door three times. Three times I raised my chainsword. Three times he walked past me as though I were furniture. I am done being furniture." — The anger that drives him forward.

What He Wants

Immediate: Get Ireena to safety. Fortress Vallak has walls and a garrison. Krezk has the Biologis facility. Anywhere that is not the undefended village where his father died. He needs the Acolytes' help because he cannot protect her on the road alone — the forests are full of mutants, warp-hounds, and worse.

Deeper: To prove that he is not lesser. To honour his father's memory by being the man Kolyan believed he could be. To find someone — anyone — who can explain what is happening to his world and, ideally, stop it. He does not dream of destroying Strahd; he is too practical for that. He dreams of his sister being safe and his father being proud.

What He Fears

  • Failing Ireena: This is the fear that wakes him at night. He has already failed once — his father died on his watch. If Ireena dies too, he will break.
  • Being useless: The Acolytes are Inquisitorial agents — trained, equipped, empowered by the highest authority in the Imperium. Ismark is a village PDF trooper with a three-century-old chainsword. The gulf in capability is obvious and painful. He fears being dead weight.
  • What Ireena is becoming: He has noticed her emerging psychic abilities — the moving objects, the whispered warnings. He does not know what it means, but he knows that psykers on Barovus attract the wrong kind of attention. He is afraid for her in a way he cannot articulate.
  • Strahd's indifference: Not Strahd's cruelty — his indifference. Three times Strahd came to the manor. Three times Ismark raised his weapon. Three times Strahd walked past him as though he did not exist. Being beneath notice is worse than being feared.

Reactions

Respect: Honest, direct communication earns Ismark's trust immediately. He responds to military professionalism, straightforward language, and anyone who treats Ireena with dignity. Charm (Ordinary +10) or Command (Routine +20) will earn his full cooperation.

Threats: Intimidation makes him defensive but compliant — he is too desperate to refuse help. But he remembers, and his compliance will carry a bitter edge. He has been threatened by worse than Inquisitorial Acolytes.

Questions about Strahd: He answers honestly and to the best of his ability. He knows Strahd has ruled for centuries, that the Mists prevent escape, that the Vostra can navigate the fog, and that other settlements exist but are equally wretched. He does not understand the warp, the pact, or Strahd's true nature. His information is practical, not esoteric.

Displays of faith: Ismark's faith is simple and sincere — the rough-hewn devotion of a soldier who prays before battle and does not think too deeply about theology. Genuine displays of faith comfort him. Performative piety irritates him.

Displays of weakness: He is surprisingly understanding, because he fights his own weakness every day. He will not mock or judge a struggling Acolyte. He will offer a hand, a grim joke, and the implicit message: We keep going.

Unexpected competence: If an Acolyte demonstrates exceptional skill — especially in combat — Ismark's respect is immediate and obvious. He evaluates people by what they can do, not what they claim.

Story Role

Ismark is the Acolytes' first real contact on Barovus and their introduction to the human cost of Strahd's rule. He serves three narrative functions: quest-giver (he initiates the escort mission), grounding presence (he is the most relatable, human character in the campaign's early stages), and competent ally (he provides reliable combat support during Acts I and II). His arc — from desperate brother to potential leader — mirrors the campaign's broader themes of ordinary people finding courage in extraordinary circumstances.

He is also a barometer for the Acolytes' behaviour. If they treat him well, he becomes loyal to the death and grows into a confident, capable leader. If they dismiss him, he becomes reckless, taking increasingly dangerous risks to prove his worth — which may get him killed. How the Acolytes treat Ismark is, in a sense, the first moral test of the campaign.

Common GM Questions

How tough should Ismark be in combat?

Reliable but not dominant. He should contribute meaningfully — dropping a mutant, covering fire, holding a doorway — without overshadowing the Acolytes. His WS and BS of 40 mean he hits roughly half the time, which feels right for a competent-but-not-exceptional soldier.

Should Ismark travel with the party for the entire campaign?

Typically through Acts I-II. Once Ireena reaches a defensible location, Ismark may stay to protect her while the Acolytes explore further. If drawn as the Destined Ally (Tarot Draw 1: The Warrior), he remains through the final battle. Otherwise, his role naturally transitions from active companion to background NPC once Ireena is established somewhere safe.

What if the Acolytes get Ismark killed through carelessness?

Ireena's reaction is the consequence. She will hold the Acolytes responsible — not with screaming, but with cold, wounded silence and a visible withdrawal of trust. Mechanically, her cooperation drops: she becomes harder to persuade, less forthcoming with information, and more likely to make independent (potentially reckless) decisions. Ismark's death should carry weight.

Madam Eva sits at a low table in the centre of her caravan. She is old — impossibly old, her face a map of deep wrinkles, her eyes milky with cataracts that somehow do not impair her sight. She is wrapped in shawls and scarves of faded silk, her fingers heavy with rings that clink softly as she shuffles a deck of hand-painted cards. Incense hangs thick in the air — not the cloying sweetness of Slaanesh but something older, earthier, like burnt sage and sacred oils. The candles — dozens of them, real wax — fill the space with flickering amber light.

She looks up as you enter, and her clouded eyes fix on you with an intensity that makes your skin prickle. "Sit," she says. Her voice is the creak of an old hinge, but beneath it is iron. "I have been waiting for you. The cards told me you were coming. They told me many things."

Background

Madam Eva's origins are obscured by time and her own deliberate obfuscation. She claims to be the oldest living human on Barovus, and there is no one alive who can contradict her. She leads the Vostra — the warp-touched Rogue Trader clan that navigates the mists — from their permanent camp at Tser Pool, a sheltered clearing beside a dark lake on the road between Barovus Village and Fortress Vallak.

She is a psyker of formidable power, though her abilities manifest exclusively through divination. She reads the Emperor's Tarot with a skill and accuracy that would make a sanctioned astropath weep. Her readings are never wrong — though they are frequently cryptic, incomplete, and open to dangerous misinterpretation. She has been sanctioned by no one, is answerable to no authority, and is sustained by means she does not explain.

There are persistent rumours — never confirmed, never denied — that she is related to Strahd von Zarovich by blood. The nature of this connection, if it exists, is one of the campaign's deepest mysteries. What is certain is that she is one of the few beings on Barovus whom Strahd cannot dominate, cannot scry, and cannot fully predict. He tolerates the Vostra because they are useful; he tolerates Eva because he has no choice.

Appearance & Demeanour

Eva is ancient beyond easy reckoning — her face a topography of wrinkles so deep they seem carved, her frame shrunken and bent beneath layers of shawls, scarves, and jangling charms. Her eyes are milky white, blind for decades, yet they track movement and fix on individuals with unerring precision. Her fingers, heavy with tarnished rings, move with a dexterity that belies her age, particularly when handling the Tarot. She smells of incense, old silk, and something indefinably other — the faint ozone scent of someone who has spent a lifetime immersed in psychic energy.

Her voice shifts without warning between a grandmotherly rasp and the cold, resonant tone of genuine prophecy. She laughs often — a dry, crackling sound — and her sense of humour is dark, occasionally cruel, and always unsettling. She moves slowly but with purpose, aided by a walking stick she could theoretically use as a weapon but never does. The warp flows around her like water around a stone; psyker Acolytes will feel her presence as a still, calm point in the perpetual psychic static of Barovus.

Personality Core

Madam Eva is ancient, inscrutable, and darkly amused by the suffering of others — not from cruelty, but from the weariness of a woman who has watched the same tragedies repeat for centuries. She speaks in riddles not because she enjoys confusion (though she does) but because the future she perceives is genuinely non-linear and cannot be expressed in straightforward language. She has seen empires rise and fall within the microcosm of Barovus. She has watched good people die horribly and terrible people prosper. She has, perhaps, stopped caring which is which — or perhaps she cares so deeply that detachment is the only way to endure.

She is neither good nor evil in any simple sense. She serves the Tarot — the will of fate, or the Emperor, or whatever force guides the cards — and that service supersedes all other loyalties. If the cards say the Acolytes must suffer, she will not intervene. If the cards say they must be warned, she will speak. She regards the Acolytes as pieces on a game board, with something that might be affection or might be the fondness a player feels for a particularly interesting pawn.

She knows things she should not know. She knows the Acolytes' names before they speak them. She knows what they had for breakfast. She knows the secret fears they have never spoken aloud. This is unnerving by design. She wields this knowledge not as a weapon but as a reminder: in this place, nothing is hidden from those with the sight to see.

Voice & Mannerisms

Eva's voice is the creak of an old hinge — dry, rasping, and deceptively fragile. It shifts without warning: one moment she is a kindly grandmother offering recaf and sympathy, the next she is a prophet delivering truths that cut to the bone. She speaks slowly, choosing words with care, and leaves silences that are heavier than speech. Her blind eyes fix on the speaker with uncomfortable accuracy. She shuffles her Tarot deck constantly — a nervous habit or a ritualistic compulsion, impossible to tell.

Example Quotes:

  • "You carry the Emperor's light in a lantern made of faith. I suggest you check the oil, child. The night here is long, and the wind is hungry."
  • "The lord of this domain? Oh, I have known him since before his first death. We understand each other, he and I. He does not love me. I do not fear him. It is a satisfactory arrangement."
  • "You want me to speak plainly? Very well. You will suffer. Some of you will break. The cards do not say which — only that the breaking will matter." [pause] "Was that plain enough?"
  • "No, no — do not ask me what the card means. You already know. You knew before I turned it. You simply lack the courage to say it aloud."
  • "I am old, Acolyte. Old enough to remember when the Emperor's light touched this world without the fog swallowing it first. Old enough to remember the name of the man who brought the darkness. Some nights, I remember his face as a boy." [She says nothing more.]

What She Wants

Eva wants the cycle to end. She has watched Strahd pursue Tatyana's reincarnations for centuries, watched hope arrive and be extinguished, watched the domain grind down everything that enters it. She serves the cards because the cards — she believes — serve the Emperor's design, and the Emperor's design must eventually include an ending. Whether that ending is liberation or annihilation, she does not claim to know. She aids the Acolytes because the cards indicate they are significant. She does not promise them success.

What She Fears

That there is no ending. That the cycle is eternal, that the cards are merely reflecting her own desperate hope back at her, and that she will watch another group of brave souls march into the Spire and never return. Beneath the mystical detachment, Eva is exhausted. She hides this well.

Story Role

Madam Eva is the campaign quest-giver. Her Emperor's Tarot reading in Act I determines the locations of the three relics (Dawn's Edge, Rosette of Saint Markovia, Tome of Strahd), the identity of the Acolytes' destined ally, and the location of Strahd's final confrontation. This single scene shapes the entire campaign's structure. She also serves as a recurring oracle — the Acolytes may return to the Vostra camp for additional readings (one per day, cryptic and symbolic) and for the safety of the camp's warp-warded perimeter.

Key Scenes

  • The Tarot Reading (Act I, Chapter 4): The pivotal scene. Eva performs the five-card reading that determines the campaign's key variables. Play this with maximum theatricality — dim the lights, lower your voice, take your time. Every card should feel momentous. Address each Acolyte individually with at least one unsettlingly accurate personal observation.
  • Return Visits: The Acolytes may return for guidance at any point during Act II. Eva provides one truthful (but cryptic) answer per day via True Divination. She becomes more forthcoming as the Acolytes accomplish notable deeds.
  • Pre-Final Battle: If the Acolytes visit before assaulting the Spire, Eva provides her most direct counsel yet — still metaphorical, but with genuine tactical value. She may also reveal fragments of her personal history with Strahd, depending on how much the GM wishes to disclose.

Relationships

  • Strahd: Complex, unspoken history. Possibly blood relatives. Mutual respect tempered by mutual wariness. Strahd cannot dominate or scry her. She serves him in the sense that the Vostra operate under his sufferance, but she actively aids those who oppose him. Neither will explain this contradiction.
  • The Vostra: She commands the loyalty of most, but not all. A faction led by Arrigal secretly serves Strahd as spies and kidnappers. Eva knows this. Her tolerance of Arrigal's treachery suggests a deeper game.
  • Van Richten: She is aware of him. He is wary of her, suspecting divided loyalties. They have never met directly (or so Van Richten believes).
  • The Acolytes: Pieces on a board she did not design but can read. Affection that may be genuine or may be a seer's attachment to figures of prophetic significance.

Quest Hooks

  • The Vostra will trade with the Acolytes at fair prices — a rare safe source of basic weapons, ammunition, and medical supplies.
  • Completing tasks for the Vostra improves trade terms (Friendly prices, -25%) and grants one free piece of rare equipment per major quest.
  • Eva can guide travel through the Mists without disorientation or Insanity effects — or instruct the Acolytes in safe routes.
  • If the Tarot drew "The Blinded Seer," Eva herself may be the destined ally — though her aid comes with conditions the Acolytes may not understand until too late.

Common GM Questions

Can Eva just tell the Acolytes everything?

No. Her True Divination gives one cryptic answer per day. She genuinely cannot express the future in straightforward terms — it is non-linear and conditional. She also chooses not to reveal certain things, believing that knowledge given too freely robs it of meaning. If players press, she deflects with riddles or blunt statements: "I have told you what the cards allow. Ask again tomorrow, and perhaps they will allow more."

Is she trustworthy?

Yes and no. She will never deliberately lead the Acolytes into a trap. Her readings are genuine. But she has her own agenda — the ending of the cycle — and she will withhold information if she believes premature knowledge would change the outcome for the worse. She is playing a game measured in centuries. The Acolytes are playing one measured in days.

What is her relationship with Strahd?

Deliberately ambiguous. The design documents hint she may be related to him by blood — possibly his mother, possibly a more distant ancestor. Neither will confirm this. The GM may reveal as much or as little as serves the campaign. What is mechanically certain: she is immune to his powers, and he cannot or will not move against her.

What happens if the Acolytes attack her or the Vostra?

The Vostra camp's warp-wards impose -20 on all hostile actions within the perimeter. Psychic attacks rebound on the caster. Eva's personal Unreadable aura extends 5m. The Vostra warriors (approximately 20 combat-capable adults) will defend the camp. If Eva is killed, the Tarot reading cannot be repeated, Vostra trade ceases, and safe Mist navigation becomes impossible — the campaign becomes significantly harder. Strahd does not intervene but is privately furious. This should be treated as a catastrophic failure state.

The hab-unit is small, cluttered, and obsessively organized. Every surface is covered in parchment — hand-drawn maps, transcribed vox-intercepts, autopsy sketches, and pages upon pages of dense, cramped handwriting. A string of twine crisscrosses the room at head height, pinned with notes and connected by coloured thread in a web of associations that might be brilliant analysis or might be madness. The air smells of recaf, counterseptic, and old fear.

The man who opens the door holds a laspistol in a hand that does not quite tremble. He is old — perhaps seventy standard years, perhaps older, his face a topography of scars and hard-won survival. His eyes, behind cracked magnifying lenses, are sharp and immediately hostile.

"You have ten seconds to explain how you found me," he says, "before I decide whether you are agents of the Inquisition or agents of the Spire. I assure you, I will know if you lie."

Background

Inquisitor Rudolph Van Richten of the Ordo Malleus entered the Barovus warp rift forty-seven years ago at the head of a six-person retinue: two Acolytes, a sanctioned psyker, a Sororitas hospitaller, a savant, and a gun-servitor. Within a month, they were all dead. The psyker was the first to fall — the ambient warp energy overwhelmed her defences and she had to be put down. The others followed, picked off by Strahd's minions or driven mad by the environment. Van Richten alone survived, through a combination of extreme competence, ruthless pragmatism, and sheer, stubborn refusal to die.

He has spent the intervening decades in hiding, moving between settlements under assumed identities, compiling an exhaustive dossier on Strahd, the rift, and the power structures of Barovus. His current primary identity is "Dr. Richtus," a travelling physician in Fortress Vallak — plausible enough on a world desperate for medical care. His secondary cover, "Rictavio," is a flamboyant carnival master whose gaudy wagon in the Stockyard district conceals a captured warp-beast — a minor daemonic entity bound in a warded cage that Van Richten keeps for study.

He is a shadow of the Inquisitor he once was — old, gaunt, paranoid, and haunted by the deaths of his retinue — but his mind remains sharp and his data-slate contains information that could mean the difference between victory and annihilation. He has tried to assault Zarovich Spire twice. He failed twice, losing people each time. He will not try again alone. But he has never abandoned his duty.

Appearance & Demeanour

A gaunt man in his late seventies (or older — the warp's effect on ageing is unpredictable), with thinning white hair, a deeply lined face, and eyes that never stop moving. One eye is augmetic, glowing a faint red. He walks with a pronounced limp from an old injury that healed badly. His hands shake — not from fear, but from nerve damage sustained fighting entities that should not exist. He wears civilian clothing — a physician's coat, travel-stained and patched — with his Inquisitorial rosette sewn into the lining where it cannot be seen.

He speaks with quiet authority and the measured cadence of a man who has spent decades choosing every word carefully, because the wrong word could mean death. He carries the weight of every comrade he has buried in his posture — stooped, as though physically pressed down by accumulated grief. Yet beneath the damage, his gaze is that of a predator: watchful, analytical, ceaselessly cataloguing threats and exits. He talks to his dead retinue when he thinks no one is listening.

Personality Core

Van Richten is a man held together by willpower and bitterness. He trusts no one — least of all himself, given that he has spent decades exposed to warp corruption without the benefit of regular sanctioning. He is prone to long, suspicious silences, sudden bursts of agitation, and an unsettling habit of talking to his dead retinue when he thinks no one is listening. He has constructed elaborate mental defences against the despair that would otherwise consume him: rigid routine, obsessive documentation, and the cold comfort of data.

Beneath the damage, however, there remains a core of genuine conviction. He is an Inquisitor of the Ordo Malleus. He has a duty. He has not abandoned it — he has simply been unable to fulfil it alone. The arrival of the Acolytes represents both his greatest hope and his greatest terror: hope that they are the reinforcements he has prayed for, and terror that they will die as his retinue died, and that he will be left alone again with nothing but his data-slates and his ghosts.

He is not a leader anymore. He is an intelligence asset — and he knows it. The shift from Inquisitor to informant is a wound to his pride that has never healed. He compensates with brusque authority and occasional flashes of the commanding presence he once possessed, but these moments are followed by visible exhaustion, as though remembering who he used to be costs him something physical.

Voice & Mannerisms

Van Richten speaks precisely, clinically, as though delivering an after-action report. He favours short declarative sentences and dislikes speculation. When emotional content breaks through — anger, grief, rare moments of dark humour — it arrives suddenly and retreats just as fast, like a creature surfacing from deep water. He adjusts his cracked magnifying lenses constantly. He checks exits. He never sits with his back to a door.

Example Quotes:

  • "I have been on this world for forty-seven years, three months, and eleven days. I know because I count. Counting is how I prove to myself that time still moves forward in this place. Some days, I am not convinced it does."
  • "Strahd is not a daemon. He is not a psyker. He is something the Imperium does not have a classification for, and that terrifies me far more than any entity in the Ordo's catalogues. We have protocols for daemons. We have nothing for him."
  • "You want to assault the Spire? Admirable. I tried twice. The first time I lost three people. The second time I lost the rest. I suggest you listen very carefully to what I am about to tell you, or you will lose everyone."
  • "Trust? You ask an Inquisitor who has spent half a century in a warp-saturated hellworld to trust strangers who arrived yesterday. Show me your rosette. Recite your Ordo ciphers. Then we will discuss trust."
  • [Quietly, almost to himself] "Elara would have known what to do. She always knew. But Elara is dead, and I am here, and the work remains."

What He Wants

To destroy Strahd. To redeem his failure. To see the warp rift collapse and the Emperor's light return to Barovus. Failing all of that — to die with purpose, to ensure his death means something, and to pass his decades of intelligence to someone who can use it. He has made peace with his own death; he simply refuses to let it be meaningless.

What He Fears

That the Acolytes will die as his retinue died. That his intelligence is insufficient. That the decades of warp exposure have corrupted him in ways he cannot detect. That he has gone mad and does not know it — that the web of analysis pinned to his walls is the work of a broken mind, not a brilliant one. And deepest of all: that the Emperor has abandoned Barovus, and his faith is directed at an empty throne.

Story Role

Van Richten is the campaign's primary intelligence source. He does not fight the final battle (he is too old and too damaged), but he provides the knowledge that makes victory possible. His data-slates contain the single most comprehensive collection of intelligence on Strahd in existence: behavioural patterns, known weaknesses, thrall identities, an incomplete but invaluable layout of the Zarovich Spire, and his critical theory that the warp rift is a deliberate construct maintainable through Strahd's pact — and that severing the pact will collapse the rift. Without his information, the Acolytes are operating blind.

Key Scenes

1. The Investigation (Act II, Fortress Vallak)

Finding Van Richten is an investigative quest chain woven into the Acolytes' time in Fortress Vallak. It proceeds through several stages:

  • The Martikovs at the Blue Water Inn know of "Dr. Richtus" and can point the Acolytes toward him (Challenging (+0) Fellowship test, with bonuses for helping the Martikovs or opposing Strahd).
  • Alternatively, the Acolytes may encounter "Rictavio" — Van Richten's flamboyant carnival-master cover — and investigate the suspicious warded wagon in the Stockyard.
  • The climactic first meeting is a tense confrontation: Van Richten holds a laspistol and demands identification within ten seconds.

2. The Verification

Van Richten will not trust easily. Verification methods:

  • Genuine Inquisitorial identification and Ordo Malleus ciphers (automatic trust, though he still verifies)
  • Hard (-20) Charm test — builds trust slowly
  • Intimidation — works mechanically but damages the long-term relationship

3. The Intelligence Briefing

Once trust is established, Van Richten delivers a detailed briefing covering Strahd's capabilities, the three relics, the nature of the warp rift, and tactical advice for the Spire assault. This should be played as a pivotal scene — decades of research condensed into a single critical download.

4. The Carnival Wagon Crisis

Van Richten's secondary cover (Rictavio's carnival wagon) conceals a captured minor daemonic entity in a warded cage. If the wards fail or the wagon is damaged — by the Acolytes' actions, Strahd's agents, or simple accident — the beast escapes into populated Fortress Vallak. This creates an urgent side-crisis and potentially exposes Van Richten's true nature.

Relationships

  • The Acolytes: Hope and terror in equal measure. He will test them relentlessly before trusting them, then support them with everything he has. He will not accompany them to the Spire but will remain in Fortress Vallak as a strategic advisor and fallback contact.
  • Strahd: Cold, focused hatred. Strahd is dimly aware of Van Richten's presence and has not bothered to eliminate him — partly because the old Inquisitor poses no real threat, and partly because hunting him might be entertaining later. This casual dismissal enrages Van Richten more than any active persecution would.
  • Madam Eva: Wary suspicion. He suspects divided loyalties and does not trust her motives. "She sees everything and tells nothing. That is either wisdom or treachery, and I have insufficient data to determine which."
  • Vallakovich: Grudging respect for the man's discipline, contempt for his methods. Van Richten uses the regime's paranoia as cover — a physician in a surveillance state is above suspicion as long as he heals the right people.

Common GM Questions

How long has Van Richten actually been on Barovus?

The design documents state forty-seven years since entry. However, warp time dilation on Barovus may mean this equates to a different span of subjective experience. For practical purposes, he has been there long enough to become the foremost living expert on Strahd and long enough to have lost everything except his mission.

Why hasn't Strahd killed him?

A combination of factors: Van Richten is genuinely skilled at hiding, Strahd's attention is divided across an entire world, and — most damningly — Strahd simply does not consider Van Richten a serious threat. The old Inquisitor is a curiosity, a mouse in the walls of his domain. Strahd is aware of his existence and has not bothered to eliminate him because hunting him might be entertaining later. This casual dismissal is, for Van Richten, worse than active persecution.

Can the Acolytes use his cover identities?

Yes, with care. "Dr. Richtus" is a respected local physician — the Acolytes can use his medical practice as a safe meeting point. "Rictavio" is more conspicuous. If either cover is blown, Van Richten must relocate immediately or be discovered by Strahd's agents within 1d5 days.

What if the Acolytes get him killed?

His data-slates survive if the Acolytes can recover them from his hab-unit within 24 hours. After that, Strahd's agents sanitize the location. Losing Van Richten is a major setback — the campaign becomes significantly harder without his intelligence bonuses. The emotional impact should be played for maximum effect: another name on the list of people who died because of Strahd.
