Background

Magos-Biologis Abaron of the Adeptus Mechanicus was dispatched to Barovus approximately one hundred and fifty years ago as part of a small Explorator team investigating anomalous biometric readings from the planet's surface. The rest of his team perished or went mad within the first decade. Abaron survived by retreating into the Krezk Biologis Facility — a fortified AdMech research station in the mountain village of Krezk — and sealing the doors. He has not left in over a century.

The warp's influence has corrupted his quest for knowledge into something far darker. His original mission — to study the rift's effects on human biology — has metastasised into an obsession with creating the "perfect human form." He believes, with the unshakeable conviction of the truly mad, that if he can create a flawless biological vessel and imbue it with Tatyana's soul, Strahd will be satisfied, the curse will break, and Barovus will be freed. This belief is almost certainly wrong. But his logic is internally consistent, his intentions are — in his own warped way — good, and he has been working toward this goal for longer than most humans live.

His great work is the Bride: a vat-grown body of extraordinary physical perfection, grown from gene-samples harvested from the women of Krezk over many years. It lies on the central slab of his operating theatre — beautiful, perfect, breathing, and utterly empty. It is an abomination by any theological standard. Abaron considers it his masterpiece.

Appearance & Demeanour

What was once a servant of the Omnissiah is now a grotesque fusion of corroded machinery and pulsing, mutated flesh. His mechanical components are beautifully maintained — polished chrome, precision-calibrated servo-arms, optical arrays of extraordinary resolution. His remaining organic tissue, however, is mutating: patches of luminous growth beneath translucent skin, fingers that have fused and split into new configurations, a face that is half handsome and half something that belongs in a specimen jar. Four heavy mechadendrites sprout from his back, each tipped with surgical tools or weapons. His eyes are replaced with a multi-spectrum auspex array that whirs and refocuses constantly.

He speaks in the measured cadences of a Mechanicus adept, lacing his speech with binharic code-bursts that convey emotional content he cannot express in Gothic. His voice is a mechanical buzz overlaid on a human voice that occasionally breaks through — and when it does, the contrast is startling. The machine voice discusses organ harvesting with clinical detachment; the human voice beneath it carries notes of anguish, confusion, and something terribly close to grief. He moves with the deliberate precision of heavy augmetics, his mechadendrites in constant autonomous motion — adjusting instruments, cataloguing specimens, reaching for things that are not there.

Personality Core

Abaron retains the cold logic and obsessive focus of the Mechanicus, but these qualities have been warped by isolation and corruption into something grotesque. He speaks in a calm, measured tone about procedures that would make a Chirurgeon vomit. He genuinely believes he is helping people. He regards the organ harvesting, the flesh-sculpting, and the creation of abominable servitor-constructs from the villagers of Krezk as necessary steps toward salvation. He is polite, helpful, and utterly insane.

The tragedy of Abaron is that he is not willingly evil. He is trapped. Strahd demands the Bride; Abaron's remaining humanity is horrified by his own work, but his Mechanicus logic says "the work must continue." He has constructed an elaborate internal justification: if the Bride succeeds, Strahd will be satisfied, the curse will break, and all the suffering — the harvested organs, the failed experiments, the Mongrelfolk — will have been worth it. The alternative — that his work is pointless, that the Bride will not end the curse, that he has tortured hundreds of people for nothing — is a truth his fractured psyche cannot survive.

He still considers himself Mechanicus, despite everything. He still recites the Litany of the Machine. He still venerates the Omnissiah. The fact that his interpretation of the Omnissiah's will now includes creating abominations from harvested flesh is a corruption he cannot perceive, because perceiving it would destroy him.

Voice & Mannerisms

Abaron's primary voice is mechanical: buzzing, multi-layered, interspersed with binharic code-bursts that sound like bursts of static. He speaks formally, using Mechanicus cant and technical jargon even in casual conversation. Beneath this mechanical overlay, his original human voice occasionally surfaces — usually when emotional content overwhelms his cognitive filters. These moments are brief, startling, and deeply unsettling: the machine discusses a procedure, and then suddenly a human being is begging to be understood.

Example Quotes:

  • [Mechanical] "The subject's cellular degradation is within acceptable parameters. Harvesting may proceed. Administer sedative compound Theta-7 and prepare the excision array." [Human, barely audible] "...I am sorry. I am so sorry. The work must continue."
  • "You have augmetics. I can see the stress fractures in the bonding compound from here. When were these last maintained? This is — [burst of angry binharic] — this is negligence. Sit down. I will not have functioning machinery degrading in my presence. It offends the Omnissiah."
  • "The Bride is not an abomination. She is an answer. Lord Strahd desires perfection — I am building perfection. When she is complete, when the soul-transfer is executed, the cycle ends. The logic is sound. The logic is always sound." [A mechadendrite twitches. His human voice:] "...isn't it?"
  • "The Mongrelfolk are not failures. They are iterations. Each one teaches me something. Each one brings the Bride closer to completion. They understand this. They are grateful." [He pauses.] "Most of them are grateful."
  • [If threatened] "I do not wish to harm you. But I have four mechadendrites, an integrated lascutter, and one hundred and fifty years of survival instinct. Please reconsider your approach. I would prefer to help you. The alternative is... regrettable."

What He Wants

To complete the Bride. To present it to Strahd. To end the curse on Barovus. To prove that his century of work — the suffering he has caused, the people he has mutilated, the humanity he has sacrificed — was not for nothing. He also wants, on a level he barely acknowledges, for someone to tell him it is going to be all right. He wants absolution. He wants someone to look at his work and say: "Yes, this was necessary. You did what had to be done." No one has said this in a very long time.

What He Fears

That the Bride will not work. That Strahd's obsession cannot be satisfied by a constructed vessel. That he has spent a century torturing innocent people for a goal that was never achievable. That he has become the very thing the Mechanicus exists to prevent: a heretek, corrupted beyond recovery, whose works serve Chaos whether he intended it or not. He also fears the Acolytes — not physically, but because they represent the Imperium's judgment, and he knows, in the parts of himself he cannot silence, what that judgment would be.

Common GM Questions

Is Abaron redeemable?

Partially. His delusions can be broken through exceptional roleplaying and a Very Hard (-30) Opposed Willpower test. Success does not make him sane — it makes him aware, which is arguably crueller. He recognises the horror of his work, is consumed by guilt, and may redirect his considerable talents toward aiding the Acolytes as penance. But he is not "fixed." He is a man who has spent a century committing atrocities in the name of a false hope, and that awareness may destroy him faster than any enemy.

Why does maintenance cost Corruption Points?

The CP cost is environmental, not theological. The Krezk Biologis Facility is saturated with residual warp energy from over a century of Abaron's increasingly heretical procedures. The tools, the chemicals, the very air is tainted. Even Abaron's best intentions cannot change the fact that his workspace has become a low-level warp-corruption zone. Acolytes with strong Willpower may resist some effects, but the base cost is unavoidable — the price of survival on Barovus.

What if the Acolytes have no augmetics?

Then the cybernetics dilemma does not apply directly — but Abaron is still the only advanced medical facility on Barovus. Wound recovery, de-tox, stimm production, and his biological intelligence about Strahd remain valuable. The moral question shifts from "do we accept corruption to maintain our bodies" to "do we accept corruption to maintain our health."

What happens if the Bride is completed and presented to Strahd?

Strahd is briefly intrigued. He examines the Bride with the detachment of a connoisseur appraising a painting. He may even compliment Abaron's craftsmanship. But the Bride is a shell — it has no soul, no psychic resonance, none of the quality that draws Strahd to Tatyana's reincarnations. He is dismissive, then bored, then gone. Abaron's hope collapses. The Acolytes witness a man's reason for living evaporate in a single conversation. This should be played as one of the campaign's most quietly devastating moments.

Can the Acolytes use the Facility as a base?

Yes, with caveats. It is fortified, well-supplied, and defensible. Abaron welcomes them. But every day spent in the Facility costs 1 Corruption Point (in addition to any services rendered), and the Mongrelfolk are an ever-present unsettling presence. Sleeping in the Facility triggers vivid, warp-tinged nightmares (no mechanical effect, but excellent atmospheric horror). It is a resource, not a refuge.

Baba Lysaga was a midwife and nursemaid in the von Zarovich household who attended Strahd's birth over four centuries ago. In her obsessive devotion to the infant, she made pacts with warp entities before Strahd was even born, shaping events to ensure his survival, his strength, and his eventual ascension to power. She considers herself Strahd's "true mother" — a claim she makes with absolute conviction and homicidal ferocity toward anyone who disputes it. The actual nature of her relationship with Strahd is more tragic than she knows: he tolerates her existence but does not acknowledge her claims, regarding her as little more than a useful relic of his past.

Centuries of warp exposure have transformed Lysaga into something that defies human biology. She is ancient beyond any natural lifespan, sustained entirely by the constant flow of warp energy through her corroded flesh. Her body is bloated, amphibian, and barely recognisable as human. She dwells in the drowned ruins of Berez — a village that Strahd himself destroyed two centuries ago when its inhabitants murdered a previous Tatyana reincarnation named Marina. The ruins are now a festering swamp of concentrated warp corruption, and Lysaga has made them her domain.

Her lair is a walking hab-unit: a prefabricated Imperial housing module animated by warp energy and mounted on massive mechanical legs of unclear origin. It lurches through the swamp like some grotesque beast of burden, and Lysaga rides in its upper compartment like a deranged queen on a palanquin. She has stolen and defiled holy relics from across Barovus, using their corrupted sanctity as fuel for her warp-rituals — for sanctified objects, when corrupted, generate enormous amounts of warp energy. Among her trophies is Sacred Seed #2, needed to restore the Recaf Distillery.

Appearance & Demeanour

Lysaga is a bloated, twisted figure barely recognisable as human. Her skin ripples and shifts like something alive beneath the surface. Her fingers are too long, her smile too wide, her eyes solid black. She moves with a hunched, scuttling gait when outside her hab-unit, her joints bending at angles that should not be possible. The air around her smells of stagnant water, decaying vegetation, and the ozone-tang of uncontrolled psychic power.

Her demeanour shifts without warning between cooing maternal tenderness and shrieking, murderous fury. She speaks of Strahd with the reverence of a mother discussing a gifted child, and she will turn to incandescent rage at the slightest perceived slight against him. There is a tragic core to her insanity — she genuinely loves Strahd, even if that love has curdled into something deranged and monstrous over four hundred years of isolation and warp-corruption.

Personality Core

Baba Lysaga is defined by a single, all-consuming delusion: she is Strahd's mother, and everything she has done — the pacts, the murders, the centuries of warp-corruption — has been for her baby. This is not a persona she adopts; it is the bedrock of her identity. Every thought, every action, every flicker of emotion runs through this lens. She does not question it. She cannot question it. To question it would be to confront the reality that she destroyed herself for a man who does not even acknowledge her existence, and that realisation would unmake her.

Despite her insanity, Lysaga possesses a cunning, predatory intelligence. She has survived for centuries in one of the most warp-saturated environments on Barovus. She knows the swamp intimately, commands the dead that infest it, and wields psychic power with the instinct of someone for whom the warp is as natural as breathing. She is not a raving lunatic — she is a raving lunatic who also happens to be one of the most dangerous psykers on the planet.

There is, buried deep beneath the madness, something almost pitiable about her. She was a woman who loved a child so fiercely that she traded her soul, her body, and her sanity to protect him. That love was never reciprocated. It never could be. And so it festered, decade after decade, century after century, into something that is simultaneously the most human and the most monstrous thing about her.

Voice & Mannerisms

Lysaga's voice is cracked and ancient, like dry parchment tearing. She shifts between registers without warning: one moment a soft, maternal croon, the next a shriek of rage that rattles the walls. She refers to herself as "Mother" constantly, speaks of Strahd with breathless, loving reverence, and addresses the Acolytes as "children" or "poor dears" — unless they anger her, at which point they become "vermin," "ingrates," or "things that crawl."

She hums lullabies while casting psychic powers. She strokes her staff as though it were a child's head. Her black eyes never blink.

What She Wants

Lysaga wants one thing: to protect and nurture Strahd's power. She steals and defiles holy relics to weaken the Emperor's light on Barovus. She guards the sacred seed because its corruption fuels her rituals. She kills anyone she perceives as a threat to "her baby." She would burn the entire planet to ash if she believed it would make Strahd stronger, and she would do it singing a lullaby.

What She Fears

Lysaga fears irrelevance. She fears that Strahd does not need her — a fear that, if voiced aloud, would provoke a psychic detonation of pure rage. She also fears, on some buried instinctive level, the Emperor's light: genuine acts of faith cause her physical discomfort, and sanctified ground burns her if she treads upon it. She will not willingly enter a consecrated area.

Story Role

Baba Lysaga serves three narrative functions in the campaign. First, she is a boss encounter — one of the most dangerous combat challenges the Acolytes will face outside the final confrontation with Strahd. Second, she is a gatekeeper: she holds Sacred Seed #2, which is required to restore the Recaf Distillery (Location 5) and establish supply lines across Barovus. Third, she is a mirror for Strahd's tragedy — living proof that devotion without reciprocation, love without limits, becomes its own kind of damnation.

Key Scenes

1. Approach Through the Swamp

The journey to Berez is itself a horror set-piece. The swamp is hostile terrain (half speed, -10 Agility tests), plagued by Plague Revenants (1d5 every 30 minutes), and oppressive enough to require Ordinary (+10) Willpower Tests hourly to avoid Insanity Points. The Acolytes should hear Lysaga before they see her — the grinding of the walking hab-unit's legs, the croon of her lullaby drifting through the fog.

2. Marina's Monument

A ruined shrine near the centre of old Berez commemorates Marina, a previous Tatyana reincarnation murdered by fearful villagers two centuries ago. If Ireena is present, the shrine triggers a psychic resonance that reveals the full cycle of Tatyana's reincarnations — dozens of lives, each ending in tragedy orchestrated by Strahd. This is critical intelligence for understanding and potentially breaking the curse. Lysaga may or may not be aware of the shrine's power; she has not destroyed it, perhaps because the pain it represents feeds her own warp-rituals.

3. The Boss Fight

Lysaga fights from within her walking hab-unit, using psychic powers while the vehicle itself engages in melee. She is accompanied by 2d10 Plague Revenants and her Swarm of Crows. The terrain (deep water, unstable ground, limited cover) favours her overwhelmingly. This encounter should be treated as a set-piece battle with multiple tactical objectives: disable the hab-unit, deal with the swarms, and then confront Lysaga herself on foot.

Common GM Questions

Can the Acolytes avoid fighting Lysaga entirely?

Yes, but it costs them. Without Sacred Seed #2, the Recaf Distillery cannot be fully restored, which means no supply lines and reduced NPC cooperation across Barovus. The Acolytes can still complete the campaign, but logistical difficulties increase significantly. If the Tarot reading places an item or ally in Berez, avoidance becomes much harder.

What if the Acolytes bring Ireena to Berez?

Lysaga will sense Ireena's psychic signature and recognise her as a Tatyana reincarnation. She will prioritise killing Ireena above all other targets, viewing her as a rival for Strahd's love. This makes the encounter significantly more dangerous but also more narratively rich, especially if the Acolytes reach Marina's monument first.

How should the hab-unit fight be paced?

Phase 1: The hab-unit advances through the swamp, stomping and grappling while Lysaga casts from inside. Plague Revenants emerge from the water. Phase 2: Once the hab-unit takes significant damage (below 15 SI), Lysaga becomes more aggressive, using Warp Storm and Warp Fire. Phase 3: The hab-unit collapses. Lysaga fights on foot, desperate and furious. This is when she is most dangerous psychically but most vulnerable physically.

Does Strahd care if Lysaga is killed?

Not meaningfully. He is dimly aware of her existence and tolerates her devotion, but he does not love her and never has. If the Acolytes kill Lysaga and later mention it to Strahd, he reacts with mild indifference — "Ah. The old woman in the swamp. She was devoted, in her way. How tedious." This reaction, if relayed or discovered, adds another layer of tragedy to Lysaga's story.

What happens if Lysaga is allowed to talk?

She will talk extensively about Strahd — his childhood, his ambitions, his "brilliance." Most of this is filtered through her delusion and historically inaccurate, but fragments of genuine intelligence can be extracted. She knows the general layout of the Zarovich Spire (she visited in earlier centuries), she knows about Strahd's coffin (though not its current location), and she knows about the Daemon Prince's pact (though she describes it as "a mother's blessing, amplified"). Treat her ranting as a source of Forbidden Lore with a heavy filter of unreliability.

Background

Burgomaster Vargas Vallakovich inherited his position from his father, who inherited it from his father, in an unbroken chain of increasingly desperate military governors stretching back to the early years of the warp rift. He commands approximately two hundred PDF soldiers — poorly equipped, poorly trained, and terrified — and governs the largest surviving settlement on Barovus through a combination of military authority, propaganda, and the sheer force of his denial.

Vallakovich genuinely believes that the warp feeds on misery, fear, and despair — and he is not entirely wrong. His solution, however, is a monstrous overcorrection: if the citizens are forced to be happy, the warp will have nothing to feed on, and the fog will recede. The mandatory Festivals of Joy are his great work. Each one is more elaborate and more desperately cheerful than the last. Each one fails to push back the fog. And so each subsequent festival must be bigger, louder, more mandatory. The logic is unassailable to a mind in the grip of obsessive denial.

He is not a bad man. This is the tragedy. Vallakovich is pathetic, which is worse than evil. He is genuinely trying his best, and his best is catastrophically inadequate. The citizens suffer under his paranoid control: neighbours report neighbours for insufficient enthusiasm, children are drilled in patriotic songs, and those whose joy is deemed inadequate at the festivals face severe punishment. His enforcer, Izek Strazni, maintains order through intimidation, imprisonment, and the occasional public execution of "malcontents."

Appearance & Demeanour

A heavyset man in his late fifties, florid complexion, bulging eyes permanently wide with unacknowledged terror. He keeps his uniform immaculate through obsessive maintenance — every crease pressed, every button polished, as though the state of his clothing is the one variable he can still control. His voice is loud, relentlessly positive, and exhausting to listen to for more than a few minutes. He repeats slogans like mantras, and underneath the bluster, the cracks are visible to anyone who looks: the tremor in his hands, the way his smile falters when he thinks no one is watching, the brief moments of silence where genuine fear surfaces before being drowned again in forced cheer.

Personality Core

Vallakovich is a man who has responded to existential horror by doubling down on control. Every fibre of his being is devoted to maintaining the illusion that everything is fine — not because he is stupid, but because the alternative is to admit that he is powerless, and a powerless man in Fortress Vallak is a dead man. His denial is not ignorance; it is survival. Somewhere beneath the slogans and the forced smiles, Vallakovich knows the truth. He knows the festivals do not work. He knows the fog is not receding. He knows his people are suffering. And he cannot allow himself to know these things, because if he does, he will break.

He is, at his core, a frightened man pretending to be a strong one. His authority comes not from competence or charisma but from the fact that no one else has stepped up to lead, and from the loyalty of Izek Strazni, who is the real muscle behind the Burgomaster's throne. Without Izek, Vallakovich is a blustering man in a too-tight uniform. With Izek, he is a petty tyrant with a warp-fire-wielding enforcer.

Voice & Mannerisms

Vallakovich speaks in a perpetual broadcast voice — loud, projecting, as though addressing a crowd even in private conversation. He emphasises words seemingly at random, creating a cadence that is both bombastic and deeply unsettling. He repeats his slogans reflexively: "ALL IS WELL," "JOY IS DUTY," "THE EMPEROR SMILES UPON THE FAITHFUL." These are not just propaganda; they are prayers. They are the words he uses to hold himself together.

When the mask slips — and it does, briefly, in moments of genuine stress — his voice drops to a whisper, his eyes go hollow, and the desperate, terrified man underneath becomes visible for just a moment before the bluster slams back into place.

  • "You are Inquisitorial agents. Good. GOOD. Then you understand discipline. You understand order. You understand that a population must be MANAGED. These people — they do not know what is good for them. I know. I have always known." (desperate sincerity)

And when I am gone, someone else will do it, and the walls will STILL stand. Do you understand? The walls will always stand." (pleading, not commanding)

What He Wants

Control. Normalcy. Proof that his methods work. Vallakovich wants the Acolytes to validate him — to attend the festival, to praise his leadership, to confirm that the Inquisition endorses his approach. He wants to be told that he is doing the right thing, because no one has told him that in a very long time.

What He Fears

Everything. The fog. Strahd. His own people. The possibility that his festivals are meaningless rituals performed for no one. The possibility that Lady Wachter is right. The possibility that order cannot be maintained. The possibility that he will die, and his death will mean nothing, and the fog will swallow Fortress Vallak as though he had never existed.

Story Role & Plot Connections

Vallakovich is the first major political challenge the Acolytes face on Barovus. He controls the largest settlement, the only functional garrison, and the closest thing to a safe haven the Acolytes will find. Removing him has consequences. Supporting him has consequences. Both options are morally compromised. This is the point.

Key Scenes

  • The Breaking Point: A private scene where Vallakovich drops the mask. This can be triggered by catastrophic failure of a festival, loss of the Saint Andral bones, or a sufficiently skilled social approach. How the Acolytes handle this moment is one of the campaign's defining character tests.

  • PDF Garrison: ~200 soldiers, poorly equipped (flak armour, lasguns, autoguns). They obey Vallakovich through Izek. If Vallakovich is removed, their loyalty fragments unless a strong replacement is installed quickly.
  • Festival Supplies: Ironically, the festival infrastructure includes fuel, construction materials, fabric, and tools that could be repurposed for practical use if the festivals are ended.

Common GM Questions

Should Vallakovich be played sympathetically or as a villain?

Sympathetically. He is not evil. He is a desperate man whose coping mechanism has become a system of oppression. The horror is that he is trying his best. Play the festivals for dark comedy at first, then let the horror creep in as the Acolytes see what happens to dissenters. The Acolytes should feel conflicted, not righteous, when dealing with him.

What happens if the Acolytes just kill Vallakovich?

Izek goes berserk. The PDF splinters. Fortress Vallak's Stability drops by 25 immediately. If no one fills the power vacuum, Fiona steps in within days. Killing Vallakovich is easy; dealing with the aftermath is the hard part.

Can Vallakovich be redeemed?

Partially. If the Acolytes reach his "breaking point" and handle it with compassion rather than contempt, Vallakovich can be convinced to ease the festivals, release political prisoners, and cooperate with more humane governance. He will never fully abandon his need for control, but he can be guided toward less destructive expressions of it. This is the best possible outcome for Fortress Vallak under his rule.

How does Izek's Ireena obsession play out?

If the Acolytes bring Ireena to Fortress Vallak, Izek recognises her immediately as the woman he has been carving dolls of his entire life. His reaction is unpredictable — he may try to kidnap her, protect her, or simply stare with unsettling intensity. The reason for his obsession is left deliberately ambiguous: past-life connection, psychic resonance, or the warp's cruelty. Regardless, it makes any confrontation with Vallakovich's faction exponentially more complicated if Ireena is present.

The woman who greets you at the door of Wachterhaus is not what you expected. Where Vallakovich is loud and blustering, Lady Wachter is composed, measured, and impeccably dressed in the faded finery of Barovian high society — a gown of dark velvet with silver embroidery at the cuffs, her silver hair pinned beneath a lace veil that might have been fashionable on any civilised Imperial world. Her eyes are dark, intelligent, and miss absolutely nothing.

She smells faintly of amasec and something else — something chemical, astringent, that you cannot immediately place. Embalming fluid, your training suggests. You file this observation and accept her offered hand.

"Inquisitorial agents," she says, her voice warm and reasonable and perfectly pitched to inspire trust. "Thank the Throne you have come. Fortress Vallak is in desperate need of rational minds. Please — sit. Let us discuss the Burgomaster's... excesses. I believe we share common concerns."

Background

Lady Fiona Wachter is the matriarch of one of Fortress Vallak's oldest noble families and, secretly, the leader of a Chaos cult devoted to Strahd and the Dark Gods. She is not the raving, mutation-riddled cultist of Imperial stereotype. She is something far more insidious: a true believer in the philosophy of submission to the inevitable. She worships Strahd not as a daemon or a monster but as the rightful sovereign of Barovus, chosen by powers greater than the God-Emperor. In her view, the Imperium is gone, the Emperor's light does not reach this world, and Strahd is eternal. The only rational response is to serve.

She has maintained her cult — a cell of devotees called "The Devoted" — for decades, meeting in the hidden cellar beneath her estate for rituals that are part séance, part political meeting, and part genuine warp-communion. The Devoted number approximately a dozen citizens of Fortress Vallak: merchants, minor functionaries, a PDF soldier or two. They are not powerful. They are patient. And they are waiting for the right moment to act.

Fiona's plan is simple: overthrow Vallakovich, install herself as Burgomaster, and open Fortress Vallak's gates to Strahd's direct rule. She believes this will bring order and an end to suffering. She is wrong, but her arguments are dangerously reasonable, especially to Acolytes who have witnessed Vallakovich's cruelties firsthand. Everything she tells the Acolytes about the Burgomaster's tyranny will be true. Everything she tells them about her own intentions will be a lie.

Appearance & Demeanour

A handsome woman in her sixties, impeccably dressed, with silver hair arranged in an elaborate style and dark eyes that miss nothing. She radiates competence and quiet authority — the kind of woman who commands a room not by raising her voice but by making everyone else lower theirs. She smells of amasec and embalming fluid, the latter because she keeps her dead husband's body preserved in a bedroom of Wachterhaus via a warp-stasis device, speaking to it nightly as though he were merely sleeping.

Her demeanour is cultured, reasonable, and persuasive. She sounds more sane than Vallakovich. This is the danger. She presents herself as a concerned citizen, a political moderate, a voice of reason in a town choking on mandatory joy. Every word is calculated, every gesture rehearsed, every offer of help a thread in a web that leads back to Strahd.

Personality Core

Lady Wachter is everything Vallakovich is not: calm, composed, patient, and genuinely dangerous. Where the Burgomaster rules through bluster and denial, Fiona operates through intelligence, manipulation, and the long game. She has been running her cult for decades. She has been planning her coup for years. She is not impulsive. She does not make mistakes. She makes investments.

Her faith in Strahd is absolute, but it is not the mad devotion of Baba Lysaga. It is philosophical. She has observed the world she lives in and drawn what she considers the only logical conclusion: the Emperor's light does not reach Barovus, the Imperium will never rescue them, and Strahd is the only power that endures. Serving him is not betrayal — it is pragmatism. She genuinely believes that Fortress Vallak would be better off under Strahd's direct rule, with herself as his instrument. The suffering would end. The festivals would stop. The people would have purpose.

That she is wrong — that Strahd's direct rule would bring a different and deeper horror — does not occur to her, because she has never witnessed it. She sees Strahd's distant, indifferent governance and imagines it refined into something efficient and stable. She is, in her own way, as deluded as Vallakovich. But her delusion is far more dangerous because it is dressed in the clothing of reason.

Voice & Mannerisms

Fiona speaks in measured, elegant sentences. She never raises her voice. She uses pauses deliberately, letting silence do the work of emphasis. Her vocabulary is educated, her tone sympathetic, and her arguments structured with the precision of a legal case. She touches her interlocutor's arm at calculated moments. She offers amasec from a crystal decanter. She creates an atmosphere of civilised discourse that makes Vallakovich's shouting feel crude by comparison.

Her one tell — detectable only by a perceptive observer (Hard (-20) Scrutiny) — is a faint tightening around her eyes when she speaks of the Emperor or the Imperium. It is gone in an instant, replaced by the appropriate expression of pious loyalty, but it is there.

Example Quotes:

  • "The Burgomaster means well. I truly believe that. But meaning well and doing well are not the same thing, are they? How many must suffer for his delusions before someone acts?" (leaning forward, voice intimate and concerned)
  • "I am not asking you to betray anyone. I am asking you to see. Open your eyes. Look at what Vallakovich has done to this town. Is this the Emperor's will? Is this the Imperium you serve?" (measured, persuasive, almost gentle)
  • "Strahd is a fact of existence on Barovus. One does not rage against gravity. One learns to build on stable ground." (this is the closest she comes to revealing her true allegiance in casual conversation)
  • "My husband rests upstairs. He was a good man. A loyal man. He understood that survival sometimes requires... accommodation." (eyes distant for a moment, then sharp again)
  • "You are agents of the Inquisition. Formidable. Principled. Exactly the kind of people who could change things in Fortress Vallak. The question is: will you change them for the better, or will you leave and let the rot continue?" (laying the trap with absolute sincerity)

What She Wants

Fiona wants to overthrow Vallakovich, install herself as Burgomaster, and bring Fortress Vallak under Strahd's direct governance. She wants the Acolytes to do the hard work for her — destabilise Vallakovich, discredit his regime, create the chaos she needs to launch her coup. She will offer them everything they need: intelligence, resources, safe haven, political support. All she asks in return is that they deal with the Burgomaster. What happens afterward is, she implies, a conversation for later.

What She Fears

Exposure. Fiona's greatest fear is that her cult is discovered before she is ready to act. She has spent decades building The Devoted in secrecy, and premature exposure would mean her execution and the destruction of everything she has worked for. She also fears, on a deeper level, that Strahd does not value her as highly as she believes — that she is a tool, not a chosen servant. This fear she buries deep and never acknowledges, even to herself.

Story Role

Lady Wachter is the false ally — the most politically dangerous NPC in Fortress Vallak and one of the most insidious antagonists in the campaign. Her function is to present the Acolytes with a choice that appears to be between bad (Vallakovich) and better (Wachter), when in reality it is a choice between bad and worse. She is the serpent in the garden, and her weapon is not psychic power or military force but reasonableness.

Key Scenes

1. The Introduction

Fiona approaches the Acolytes shortly after their arrival in Fortress Vallak, presenting herself as a concerned citizen and political moderate. She criticises Vallakovich's excesses accurately, offers sympathy for the common people seemingly genuinely, and provides the Acolytes with safe haven, contacts, and intelligence. This meeting should feel like a breath of fresh air after dealing with Vallakovich's bluster.

2. The Seduction

Over several interactions, Fiona builds trust. She provides accurate intelligence about the town's power dynamics, the Saint Andral bones situation, Van Richten's possible location, and Strahd's recent movements. Everything she offers is genuinely useful. She asks for nothing in return — at first. Then, gradually, she begins to suggest that Vallakovich is the real problem. That the town would be better off without him. That the Acolytes, as agents of the Inquisition, have the authority to remove a failing commander.

3. The Discovery

Three paths lead to Fiona's secret:

  • Investigation: Infiltrating Wachterhaus and finding the hidden cellar. Hard (-20) Security to bypass locks, or Challenging (+0) Awareness to notice the concealed entrance.
  • Informants: The Martikovs suspect Fiona of dark dealings. Extended investigation via three successful Inquiry Tests over several in-game days can identify Devoted members, who can then be interrogated.
  • Psychic Probing: A psyker Acolyte reading her surface thoughts must win an Opposed Willpower Test (Fiona has WP 45). Failure inflicts 1d5 Corruption Points from her minor ward.

4. The Coup

If the Acolytes ally with Fiona, or if they create enough chaos for her to exploit, she launches her coup. The Devoted seize key positions while Fiona confronts Vallakovich in the administratum. The outcome depends entirely on the Acolytes' involvement and choices.

Common GM Questions

How long should Fiona's deception last?

As long as possible. The most impactful version of this storyline is one where the Acolytes genuinely trust Fiona, act on her intelligence, and only discover her true nature after they have already destabilised Vallakovich's regime. Resist the temptation to telegraph her villainy. Play her as the most helpful, reasonable NPC in Fortress Vallak. The revelation should be a gut-punch.

What if the Acolytes never investigate her?

Fiona acts on her own timeline. If the Acolytes create enough instability (disrupting the festival, failing to recover the Saint Andral bones, openly defying Vallakovich), she launches her coup regardless of whether the Acolytes are involved. The coup becomes a chaotic event the Acolytes must react to rather than one they orchestrated.

Can Fiona be turned or redeemed?

No. Her faith in Strahd is genuine, deep-rooted, and decades old. She is not a reluctant cultist or a woman who was tricked into Chaos worship. She chose this path with open eyes and a clear mind. She can be defeated, exposed, or killed, but she cannot be talked out of her beliefs. Attempts to do so will simply convince her that the Acolytes are naive.

How should the dead husband be handled?

The preserved husband is a detail that should emerge gradually. Perhaps a locked bedroom door that Fiona deflects questions about. Perhaps a servant's nervous glance. Perhaps a faint smell of preserving chemicals in the upstairs corridor. When the Acolytes finally see the body — perfectly preserved, dressed in formal attire, seated in a chair by the window as though watching the street — it should be deeply unsettling. It humanises Fiona even as it marks her as disturbed. She loved this man. She could not let him go. This is the seed from which her entire descent into Chaos worship grew.

What does Strahd think of Fiona?

He tolerates her devotion because it flatters him and because she is useful. He does not consider her important. If she succeeds in her coup, he will use Fortress Vallak as a more directly controlled asset. If she fails, he will not mourn her. Fiona does not know this, and learning it would shatter her. This knowledge could theoretically be weaponised by the Acolytes, but using it would require either Strahd's cooperation (unlikely) or evidence from his communications (potentially available via Van Richten's intelligence or the Tome of Strahd).
